title: Christian Stankov
text: Welcome to my personal website! I am an engineer with a background in environmental engineering and a passion for digitalization. I am currently working as a process engineer at p2m Berlin, where I am responsible for the automation of planning processes. I am also a Quarto enthusiast and enjoy creating interactive content with Quarto. Feel free to reach out to me via email or connect with me on LinkedIn or GitHub.

title: JavaScript in Quarto
RStudio Environment Cleanup Guide
text: This guide provides detailed instructions for cleaning up your computing environment on both Mac and Windows to ensure a fresh setup for RStudio. Using package managers like Homebrew for Mac and Chocolatey for Windows makes the process streamlined and consistent.

title: RStudio Environment Cleanup Guide
text:
For Mac Users (Using Homebrew)

Uninstall RStudio

Open Terminal.
Use Homebrew to uninstall RStudio:
brew uninstall --cask rstudio



Remove Configuration Files

Delete RStudio settings and session data:
rm -rf ~/.rstudio-desktop
Remove RStudio’s saved application state:
rm -rf ~/Library/Saved\ Application\ State/com.rstudio.desktop.savedState
rm -rf ~/Library/Saved\ Application\ State/org.rstudio.RStudio.savedState
Delete RStudio preferences:
rm ~/Library/Preferences/com.rstudio.desktop.plist
rm ~/Library/Preferences/org.rstudio.RStudio.plist



Optional: Clean R and R Packages

Uninstall R:
brew uninstall r
Manually delete any installed R packages:
rm -rf ~/Library/R
rm -rf /Library/Frameworks/R.framework



Empty Trash

Ensure all deleted files are permanently removed by emptying the Trash.

title: RStudio Environment Cleanup Guide
text:
For Windows Users (Using Chocolatey)

Uninstall RStudio

Open an administrative command prompt or PowerShell.
Use Chocolatey to uninstall RStudio:
choco uninstall rstudio



Remove Configuration Files

Delete RStudio settings from the user directory and application data:
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:USERPROFILE\.RData"
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:USERPROFILE\.RHistory"
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:USERPROFILE\.Rprofile"
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:APPDATA\RStudio"
Remove RStudio’s desktop settings:
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:LOCALAPPDATA\RStudio-Desktop"



Optional: Clean R and R Packages

If installed with Chocolatey, uninstall R:
choco uninstall r.project
Manually delete any installed R packages:
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force "$env:USERPROFILE\Documents\R\win-library\4.x"  # Replace "4.x" with your R version



Empty Recycle Bin

Ensure that all deleted files are fully removed by emptying the Recycle Bin.

title: RStudio Environment Cleanup Guide
text:
General Maintenance Tips

Regular Updates: Keep R, RStudio, and all packages up to date. Use brew upgrade on Mac and choco upgrade all on Windows.
Backup Important Files: Regularly back up your scripts, data files, and configurations. Consider using cloud storage or external drives for backups.
Disk Cleanup: Utilize built-in system tools for disk cleanup or third-party tools to clear temporary files and other system junk to maintain system performance.

title: WebShot vs. WebShot2
text: Dieses Dokument beschreibt den Einsatz von Web Shot und Web Shot 2. Diese Tools werden verwendet, um interaktive Widgets, wie zum Beispiel Plotly-Grafiken oder Leaflet-Maps, in nicht-interaktiven Outputformaten, wie einer PDF-Datei, darzustellen.

title: WebShot vs. WebShot2
text:
Unterschiede und Kompatibilität
Bei der Verwendung von Web Shot und Web Shot 2 gibt es Unterschiede, insbesondere hinsichtlich der Kompatibilität und der Methoden, wie der Output generiert wird. Web Shot verwendet PhantomJS, welches auch über das Web Shot-Paket installiert werden kann. Im Gegensatz dazu benötigt Web Shot 2 einen Chrome- oder Chromium-Browser, um zu funktionieren, und setzt nicht mehr auf PhantomJS.

title: WebShot vs. WebShot2
text:
Aktuelle Präferenzen und Funktionen
Derzeit wird Web Shot bevorzugt, da das Resizing über die Argumente ‘fig.size’ und ‘fig.width’ unterstützt wird. Bei Web Shot 2 scheint diese Funktion momentan nicht verfügbar zu sein.

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
SysMLv2 is rapidly establishing itself as the next-generation modeling language for systems engineering. One of the most convenient ways to explore the SysMLv2 Pilot Implementation is to use it interactively inside JupyterNotebooks or JupyterLab via the SysMLv2 Jupyter Kernel. This kernel allows you to execute SysML textual notation directly in notebook cells, run magic commands, query local repositories, and interact with the SysML API server.
This guide describes a reliable, working method to install the most recent SysMLv2 Jupyter Kernel on macOS, using:

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
What is a Kernel?
A kernel is a program that runs and interprets code in a specific programming language within an interactive computing environment, such as Jupyter Notebooks or JupyterLab. It acts as a bridge between the user interface and the underlying execution environment, allowing users to write and execute code in a particular language. Additionally, kernels can provide features like magic commands.
%help
%viz

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
Prerequisites

Install Homebrew
If you haven’t already installed Homebrew, you can do so by running the following command in your terminal:
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"


Install git
If you haven’t already installed git, you can do so using Homebrew. Git is used to clone the SysML v2 Release repository.
brew install git


Install Miniconda
We use Miniconda as a lightweight package manager to manage our Python environment. Install Miniconda using Homebrew:
brew install --cask miniconda


Install jenv (Java Version Manager)
We use jenv to manage Java versions. Install jenv using Homebrew:
brew install jenv

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
Install & Activate Java
The current SysMLv2 Kernel requires Java 21. The SysML v2 Release defines the required Java version as 21 under the Install Seciton

Install Java 21
Install Java 21 using homebrew:
brew install openjdk@21


Add Java 21 to jenv
Add the installed Java version to jenv:
1jenv add /code-annotations: hover

1

Adjust the path if necessary, depending on your Homebrew installation location.




Activate Java 21 globally
Set Java 21 as the global Java version:
jenv global 21
java -version
The expected output should indicate that Java 21 is active.

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
Install JupyterLab
If JupyterLab is not already installed, you can install it using conda:
conda install jupyterlab notebook

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
Install SysMLv2 Kernel
The installation process is defined by the SysML v2 Release.

Clone the SysML v2 Release Repository
Before installing the kernel, you need to clone the SysMLv2 Pilot Implementation repository. This repository contains the Jupyter integration scripts, examples, and the SysML textual tooling.
First, navigate to your desired installation directory and clone the repository:
1cd PATH
git clone https://github.com/Systems-Modeling/SysML-v2-Pilot-Implementation.git 

1

Replace PATH with your desired installation directory.




Install the SysMLv2 Jupyter Kernel
Navigate to the Jupyter installation directory within the cloned repository and run the installation script:
cd SysML-v2-Pilot-Implementation/install/jupyter
chmod +x ./install.sh
./install.sh


Ensure Kernel Registration
Running the installation script places the SysMLv2 Jupyter kernel on your system, but it’s important to verify that Jupyter actually recognizes it. The kernel must be correctly registered so Jupyter knows how to launch the SysML engine, where the Java runtime is located, and which classpath to use.
jupyter kernelspec list
If the SysML kernel does not appear, or if you notice that the kernelspec path points to a stale directory (e.g., a conda cache), you can refresh the registration by reinstalling the Jupyter integration layer:
conda install -c conda-forge jupyter-sysml-kernel --force-reinstall
This step does not replace the SysMLv2 Pilot Implementation you cloned earlier. Instead, it ensures that Jupyter’s kernel registry is in a clean and consistent state so the SysML kernel starts reliably.

title: SysML v2 Kernel & Syside Setup
text:
Integrate SysMLv2 Kernel with VSCode (Syside)






Important



The kernel can be used within JupyterLab or Jupyter Notebooks. However, I would recommend using VSCode with the Syside Extension for a more integrated SysMLv2 modeling experience.


To use the SysMLv2 Kernel within VSCode, ensure you have the Jupyter Extension installed. This extension allows you to run Jupyter notebooks directly in VSCode. The SysMLv2 Kernel should automatically appear as an option when you create or open a Jupyter notebook.



SysMLv2 Kernel in VSCode
